newsitem.title: USA: Ex-railroad official sentenced in Alaska oil case.
newsitem.headline: Ex-railroad official sentenced in Alaska oil case.

text.p: A former supervisor for Alaska's White Pass & Yukon Railroad was sentenced in federal court on Wednesday to a year in confinement for his role in a 1994 oil spill from a company pipeline.

Edward Hanousek was ordered by U.S. District Court Judge James Fitzgerald to spend six months in prison and six months in a halfway house for a violation of the federal Clean Water Act, the U.S. Attorney's office said.
He was also ordered to pay a $5,000 fine, officials said.
Hanousek was convicted in December of negligent discharge of oil, a charge related to a spill of oil from a company pipeline into southeast Alaska's Skagway River.
He was in charge of a rock quarrying project that caused the pipeline rupture, officials said.
The former president of the railroad's owner, Pacific and Arctic Navigation Co., Paul Taylor, was also convicted of pollution violations. Taylor has not yet been sentenced.
Prosecutors said Taylor and Hanousek conspired to conceal the pipeline rupture and resulting oil spill.

Pacific and Arctic Navigation Co. and a sister company, Pacific and Arctic Pipelines Inc., last year pleaded guilty to pollution charges and agreed to pay fines and restitution of $1.5 million for the damages.
The White Pass & Yukon Railroad, a relic of the Klondike gold rush, runs from Skagway, Alaska, to the Yukon Territory. The narrow-gauge railway is a major tourist attraction.
